history.content: These are not directly related to ML/AI. Math 128A might be of a little help but not much. EE 126/127 would be more helpful. Also Math 221 could be good, since matrix computation and numerical stability are important in ML.
These are not directly related to ML/AI. EE 126/127 would be more helpful.

children.subject: Also: If you have to make a choice between taking more classes and understanding fundamental material really well, choose the latter. It is a lot more useful to know the material in EE 126, Math 110, CS 189 and Stat 135 really really well than to only sort of understand those and take 6 other classes which you also don't really understand.

I took math 128A, it wouldn't be much use as a lot of the focus is on things that aren't relevant to ML (floating point, root finding, approximating ODEs, numerical integration and differentiation). Math 128B might be of more use since there's more emphasis on numerical linear algebra, but I can't personally vouch and I'm unsure if 128A is a hard pre-req for it.

Math 104 is unnecessary if you're planning on industry but very useful if you're interested in getting into theory way down the line (i.e. you're interested in both grad school and theory). ML theory papers can go pretty deep down this route (e.g. measure theoretic probability theory, differential geometry, functional analysis for kernel methods).

+1 to EE126 (I haven't taken this). Stat 150 (stochastic processes, which I did take) is also a good class in the vein of EE126 (less work, assumes Stat 134, goes deeper into stochastic processes). EE 127 (I haven't taken this) may be useful but my impression from talking to people is that doesn't go very deep and is mostly linear algebra review so it is skippable if you're serious about ML - convex optimization in general is important though so it would be good to get exposure at some point (e.g. a grad level course).

Stat 135's material is crucial if you're interested in data science at all, though at least the current form of the class seems memorization heavy (I never took the class, though I have self-studied the material and read through the textbook). It's less useful if you're interested in pure AI/classification problem applications. Other potentially useful stat classes: Stat 210A (theoretical statistics), 238 (bayesian statistics), CS281A/Stat 241A (probabilistic graphical models), Stat 151 (linear models - I've found people trained in ML but not classical stats really underestimate the usefulness of linear models).

For prospective long-term researchers (i.e. you're willing to study for over a decade), Prof. Michael Jordan has a list of recommended textbooks here - though this list isn't really relevant until you're a phd student:

http://www.statsblogs.com/2014/12/30/machine-learning-books-suggested-by-michael-i-jordan-from-berkeley/

OP Here: Thanks for all the replies! I am actually a double in CS and Stat, so I will be done with Math 110, Stat 134, and 135 by the end of this semester. I am taking CS 189 for sure next semester, and I need to take two of these math upper division classes as I am doing math for my cluster requirement.  I am just not unsure about which one to take that will complement my career the best. Any recommendation?

history.content:
Hi, are there any good math classes to take if I want to pursue a career in ML/AI? I have already taken Math 110. I am trying to see if Math 126 (Partial Differential Equations)/Math 128A (Numerical Analysis) will be good? Or I can pick from any of these: Math 104, 105, 113, and 185.

Thanks!
history.subject: Good math classes to take for Machine Learning/AI?
